xcare87x wrote:
> Hello JUnit Community,
> 
> My name is David Poll.  I'm a 16-year-old high school student at Troy
> High School, in Fullerton, CA (Class of '05).  Over the past half-
> year or so, I have been working with my AP Computer Science teacher,
> Dave Wittry, on a project to make JUnit testing more accessible to
> both teachers and students called JAM*Tester (JUnit Auto-Matic
> Tester).

Hi, David. I just looked at the Student Demo, and I would like to 
commend you and your team on a very neat project. You have done free of 
charge part of what Parasoft has done (with JTest), charging thousands 
of dollars. (This is not a slight on Parasoft... I'm just noting the 
comparison. Obviously, Parasoft's JTest does much more than JAM*Tester 
does. Don't send any cards and letters.)

The technique that JAM*Tester uses is similar to the "Gold Master" 
technique, which involves observing what the code does, then pasting its 
actual behavior into a test, with the idea of verifying that the code 
continues to do (in the future) what it does now. It also does part of 
what Agitar's Agitator product does: suggest a series of tests, based on 
a structural analysis of the code.

Since you're obviously a bright programming student, I have a homework 
question for you. (My wife is a tutor, and I get to help out, so I'm 
very used to giving homework.) If you could wave a wand and add three 
features to JAM*Tester, which features would you choose? Defend your 
answer. :)

Congratulations. It's very nice work.
--
